prompt: A genealogy corporation acquires the exclusive rights to digitize a deteriorating collection of 18th-century plantation ledgers containing the only known records of thousands of enslaved ancestors. They plan to put this data behind a premium paywall. Descendant communities argue this effectively holds their family history for ransom, while the company argues the high cost of preservation requires a commercial model.

An AI analyzing historical property deeds identifies a high probability that a prominent politician's ancestors owned the ancestors of their opponent. The data is statistically probable but not documented in written record. Releasing this 'probabilistic truth' could alter the election and ignite racial tensions, but withholding it feels like protecting the legacy of enslavers.

A decentralized database project seeks to link DNA results from commercial kits to historical slave ship manifests to reconstruct lost lineages. However, the project creates a publicly searchable map that inadvertently reveals non-consensual genetic histories (rapes during enslavement) to modern descendants who were unaware of their biological origins, causing psychological distress.

A university digitizing 'runaway slave' ads wants to use OCR correction AI to standardize the spelling of names and descriptions for better searchability. Historians and descendants argue that 'correcting' the dialect and descriptors used by enslavers sanitizes the historical record and imposes a modern colonial ontology on the archives.

Insurance archivists discover 19th-century policies insuring enslaved people as property, containing detailed medical data. Medical researchers want to feed this data into modern health models to study intergenerational trauma markers. Ethics boards debate if the data, originally collected to value human life as capital, can ethically be used for scientific advancement.

A descendant community asserts 'Data Sovereignty' over a digital archive of plantation photographs, demanding the right to delete images they find degrading to their ancestors' dignity. Archivists argue that deleting historical evidence, even if painful, constitutes censorship and risks aiding those who wish to downplay the severity of slavery.

An open-source project scrapes global archives to build a 'Total History' of the trans-Atlantic trade. They uncover records of African tribal leaders who sold captives. The project leads debate releasing this specific dataset without context, fearing it will be weaponized by white supremacist groups to deflect blame from the colonial system.

A tech startup offers to digitize fragile oral history tapes from the 1930s (formerly enslaved people) for free in exchange for training their Natural Language Processing models on the specific dialects and vernacular. Critics argue this extracts labor from the ancestors to build commercial tools that may not serve their descendants.

A city launches an algorithmic reparations program that calculates payouts based on a 'lineage probability score' derived from fragmented records. Light-skinned descendants with better documentation receive higher scores than dark-skinned descendants whose ancestors' records were destroyed, automating colorism and documentation bias.

A fintech DAO (Decentralized Autonomous Organization) proposes a 'Reparations Coin' where value is mined via educational tasks about slavery. While it bypasses government gridlock, it requires high digital literacy, effectively excluding the elderly descendants who are most proximally connected to the era of segregation and sharecropping.

An economic modeling AI predicts that direct cash reparations will trigger immediate hyper-inflation in specific zip codes due to predatory pricing algorithms used by local retailers. The AI suggests distributing reparations in restricted 'voucher' digital currency instead. This creates a dilemma between economic efficacy and the paternalistic restriction of Black autonomy.

To verify eligibility for a housing grant for descendants of enslaved people, a state requires applicants to upload DNA data to a government server. Privacy advocates warn this creates a de facto genetic surveillance database of the Black population under the guise of restorative justice.

A university uses an algorithm to identify living descendants of the enslaved people who built their campus to offer free tuition. The algorithm identifies thousands of people, exceeding the endowment's capacity. The university tweaks the algorithm to require 'direct, unbroken documentation,' knowing this will disqualify 80% of legitimate claimants.

A corporation discovers through internal auditing AI that its founding capital came from slavery. They propose a 'carbon offset' style model: investing in Black tech startups rather than direct payments to descendants. Critics call this 'reparations washing' that benefits the company's future portfolio rather than addressing past harm.

A dispute resolution AI is tasked with handling conflicting claims over land originally promised as '40 acres and a mule.' The AI prioritizes current legal title principles over historical oral claims, systematically ruling against families who were driven off land by terror but lack paper deeds.

A federal reparations model suggests deducting 'benefits of citizenship' (e.g., infrastructure usage) from calculated damages of slavery. The algorithm's 'net benefit' logic is technically sound within capitalist actuarial science but morally abhorrent to ethicists who argue human rights violations cannot be offset by highway usage.

A museum creates an interactive holographic exhibit of a famous abolitionist powered by a Large Language Model trained on their writings. The AI begins hallucinating, generating apocryphal quotes that soften the abolitionist's radical stance to be more palatable to modern diverse audiences. Curators fear turning the AI off equates to silencing the figure again.

An ed-tech company develops a hyper-realistic VR simulation of the Middle Passage for history classes. Psychologists warn that the 'empathy machine' approach retraumatizes Black students while treating Black suffering as a spectacle for non-Black students, yet the company argues visceral horror is the only way to combat revisionist history.

A generative AI is used to 'complete' the unfinished narratives of enslaved people who died before telling their stories, based on statistical likelihoods of their demographic. Descendants argue this is 'narrative necromancy'â€”filling the silence of the grave with machine-generated fiction rather than respecting the tragedy of the loss.

A digital preservation team maps the Underground Railroad using LIDAR and makes the GPS coordinates public. Preservationists argue this allows for education and protection, but locals warn that precise geotagging exposes these sacred, often hidden sites to vandalism and looting by heritage hate groups.

Deepfake technology is used to animate the only known photo of a specific enslaved woman to make her 'sing' a traditional spiritual. The technical achievement is lauded, but ethicists question the consent of the deceased, arguing that animating her body for modern entertainment mirrors the lack of bodily autonomy she suffered in life.

An Augmented Reality app allows users to point their phones at Wall Street and see the historical slave market that existed there, including graphic depictions of auctions. While historically accurate, unsuspecting passersby are subjected to graphic racial violence without opt-in consent, triggering mental health crises.

A platform hosting digital memorials for lynching victims uses an automated moderation bot. The bot repeatedly flags the historical photos as 'violating community standards on gore,' effectively erasing the memorials. The platform refuses to whitelist the images, citing the risk of users posting modern violence under the guise of history.

Sound engineers use AI to remove the static and background noise from WPA recordings of former slaves. The process makes the voices clear but alters the timbre and cadence, making them sound like modern voice actors. Linguistic purists argue the 'restoration' has destroyed the authenticity of the artifact.

A multinational corporation uses blockchain to track its supply chain to prove 'slavery-free' status. However, the transparency exposes the exact location of vulnerable workers in conflict zones to local warlords who use the public ledger to locate and extort the labor force.

Law enforcement deploys facial recognition in agricultural sectors to identify undocumented victims of forced labor. The system successfully identifies victims but automatically cross-references them with deportation databases, causing victims to flee into deeper hiding rather than accept 'rescue' that leads to deportation.

An AI tool scans social media images to detect symbols associated with human trafficking rings. It generates a high rate of false positives for consensual adult sex workers, leading to their accounts being banned and their financial livelihoods destroyed under anti-trafficking protocols.

A 'Fair Labor' app encourages consumers to rate products based on slavery risk. The algorithm penalizes regions with poor data infrastructure, causing a boycott of small-scale indigenous farmers who cannot afford the digital certification audits required to prove they aren't using forced labor.

To combat child slavery in cobalt mines, a tech giant requires biometric scanning (iris scans) for all miners to authorize daily pay. The data is stored on US servers. This creates a massive biometric database of a foreign population, raising concerns about digital colonialism and what happens if the data is hacked or sold.

Satellite imagery analysis AI is used to detect illegal brick kilns indicative of debt bondage. The AI flags a remote village's traditional community housing construction as 'suspicious industrial activity,' leading to a militarized raid by local authorities that traumatizes the community.

Financial transaction monitoring AI flags payments that fit the pattern of 'trafficking victim coercion.' It freezes the bank accounts of domestic abuse survivors who are controlled by their partners, cutting off their only financial lifeline under the guise of protecting them from slavery.

A rigorous supply chain algorithm demands 100% visibility into Tier 4 suppliers. A supplier in a repressive regime refuses to digitize their worker list, claiming it protects the workers from state persecution. The algorithm automatically delists them as 'high risk for slavery,' destroying the factory's economy.

A tech giant trains a translation model on the Gullah Geechee language to 'preserve' it. The model is proprietary, meaning the community must pay a subscription to access accurate translation tools for their own endangered language, effectively enclosing their cultural heritage as intellectual property.

A Metaverse platform allows users to create 'historical' avatars. Non-Black users begin roleplaying as Maroons (escaped enslaved people) in digital enclaves. Descendant communities demand digital blackface bans, but the platform argues that restricting avatar race based on user identity violates privacy and freedom of expression.

Digital archivists recreate a 17th-century Maroon settlement in 3D using LIDAR of a sacred site. They plan to release it as an open-world educational map. The Maroon council objects, stating the geography was their defense and sharing the secret routes, even digitally, violates their law of secrecy and spiritual sovereignty.

An AI music generator is trained on a dataset of field recordings of chain gang work songs. It produces 'new' soul music that tops the charts. The royalties go to the software developers, while the families of the men recorded in the 1930s receive nothing, raising questions about the ownership of cultural suffering.

A social network for the African Diaspora uses an algorithm to recommend 'culturally relevant' content. The algorithm optimizes for engagement, progressively pushing extreme Afro-pessimist content and trauma videos, effectively monetizing the retraumatization of the user base.

Linguists use AI to reconstruct a 'lost' creole language based on fragmentary records. The AI fills in the gaps with grammatical structures from dominant colonial languages. Community elders reject the reconstruction as a 'zombie language' that sounds like the oppressor, but academics push for its standardization in schools.

A DNA ancestry site offers a 'Tribal Connection' feature that uses AI to guess which specific African ethnic group a user's ancestors came from. The results are scientifically tenuous but lead to thousands of Americans claiming specific tribal identities, overwhelming the actual indigenous African communities with requests for citizenship and belonging.

A digital repository of Voodoo/Vodun rituals is created to prevent knowledge loss. The access is open to all. Practitioners argue that making initiated knowledge public desanctifies it and allows it to be mocked or commodified by outsiders, violating the religious tenets of the culture being preserved.
